content.raw: Just checking…Why don’t we shuffle the messages now?
content.html: Just checking…Why don’t we shuffle the messages now?

content.raw:
Shuffling would create out-of-order packet delivery which isn’t entirely realistic in a point-to-point wireless setting \(especially when we consider unreliable transport, re-sends could potentially introduce some out-of-order delivery\).

I think shuffling was originally used to keep a single node from starving out other nodes due to rate-limiting on the shared channel. With small packet sizes, I think we are unlikely to see this happen \(certainly not in my testing\). Messages coming in from multiple clients at similar rates will mix somewhat uniformly \(so there shouldn’t be a bias in terms of service\).
content.html:
Shuffling would create out-of-order packet delivery which isn’t entirely realistic in a point-to-point wireless setting (especially when we consider unreliable transport, re-sends could potentially introduce some out-of-order delivery).

I think shuffling was originally used to keep a single node from starving out other nodes due to rate-limiting on the shared channel. With small packet sizes, I think we are unlikely to see this happen (certainly not in my testing). Messages coming in from multiple clients at similar rates will mix somewhat uniformly (so there shouldn’t be a bias in terms of service).

content.raw: I just want to make sure that I understand this correctly...Are `range_model` and `visibility_model` two options of `rf_configuration` and the user needs to choose only one of them or both models are required?
content.html: I just want to make sure that I understand this correctly...Are range_model and visibility_model two options of rf_configuration and the user needs to choose only one of them or both models are required?

content.raw: The “visibility\_range” model \(which uses visibility heuristic to adjust the parameters of the log-normal range model\) actually relies on both of these sets of configurations. I kept them separate since you can use a range model without the visibility piece.
content.html: The “visibility_range” model (which uses visibility heuristic to adjust the parameters of the log-normal range model) actually relies on both of these sets of configurations. I kept them separate since you can use a range model without the visibility piece.

content.raw: And the `log_normal_range` doesn't use the visibility information contained in the graph?
content.html: And the log_normal_range doesn't use the visibility information contained in the graph?

content.raw: Correct.
content.html: Correct.

content.raw: Thanks. Can you mention this detail in the documentation of the `CommsBrokerBlugin`? I just want to make sure that everybody understands that if you're using the `log_normal_range` comms model type you'll need extra files. On the other hand, `visibility_range` should work without any external file.
content.html: Thanks. Can you mention this detail in the documentation of the CommsBrokerBlugin? I just want to make sure that everybody understands that if you're using the log_normal_range comms model type you'll need extra files. On the other hand, visibility_range should work without any external file.

content.raw: Out of curiosity, is there any reason for using this ROS data structure here? Unless you plan to send it over the network it's probably more convenient to use something like `ignition::math::Pose3d`, which gives you all the manipulations for free. I believe you need to compute at least the distance between 3D points.
content.html: Out of curiosity, is there any reason for using this ROS data structure here? Unless you plan to send it over the network it's probably more convenient to use something like ignition::math::Pose3d, which gives you all the manipulations for free. I believe you need to compute at least the distance between 3D points.
